utterances: That view is shared by African-American businessman Cameron Thomas.
He's a realtor.
We met him and some friends at an Italian restaurant near his office back in Omaha.
The diversity that is so evident in America should be represented in our courts, should be represented in our businesses.
I think it gives a more round voice.
You know, having another woman on the court makes a lot of sense to me, too.
Cameron Thomas' friend Dan Goodwin who works for eBay says flatly a good Christian is more important to him than a black candidate.
A good example is as everybody knows most blacks would not feel that Clarence Thomas represents their views, most blacks who say, `Well, we still don't have representation in the Supreme Court.

The important thing is that there is somebody that comes in not only with a different perspective than what's already there but also with the Christian perspective and that will stand for what's right.
A human being that prays out of a sincere heart will get an answer from God.

In the early evening as the day finally began to cool down, we went to a softball game out to Dill Field in Omaha where girls 12 and under from all over the area were playing the last fast-pitch softball games of the season.
(Soundbite of ball being hit)
Mike Williams coaches a team from Papillion.
He works for the United States Strategic Command at Offutt Air Force Base.
He says the president should take the long view on this decision.
Not just for the next two or three years of his administration but what's going to benefit the country in the long run.
I'm a registered Democrat but I would like to see somebody that can take and interpret constitutional law in a balanced way.
I don't like to see it biased one way or the other.
I think it should be a balanced representation of judicial thought.
That seemed to be the bottom line for Omaha.
Most of the people we met said something similar about balance, not bias, about thoughtful decision-making and commonsense.
Linda Wertheimer, NPR News.
This is NPR News.
Estimates of the number of protesters arrested in Pakistan today vary widely.
Overall, the government has put the number at fifteen hundred.
Other groups say it's above 3,000.
And Pakistanis are finding it difficult to find out what's really going on because the TV media has been taken off the air.
NPR's Philip Reeves is in Islamabad.
If you want to know what's going on in Islamabad, drop into the city's press club.
A stark, grubby place, it has less charm than your average bus shelter.
But it's the nerve center, the gathering point for journalists who cover Pakistan's capital day in and day out.
Normally, the TV in the corner is tuned to 24-hour news.
Not anymore.
Musharraf has taken independent TV news stations off the air.
The journalists are watching a movie and, says news reporter Kemal Zemar(ph), mulling over the latest breathtaking rumor.
A rumor that Musharraf have been arrested in his house, but it was just rumor.
Rumors are always flying around in Pakistan, but this one's acquired real momentum.
(Speaking in foreign language)
It's reached this taxi driver, Mahmoud Ahmed(ph).
He wants to know if it's really true Musharraf's been arrested by the deputy army chief.
(SOUNDBITE OF PROTESTERS)
And this is the reaction when the rumor reached a crowd of loyalists protesting today against Musharraf's state of emergency.
In fact, the rumor of Musharraf's arrest's been so widespread today, the government took the unusual step of publicly denying it.
When you censor the news, rumors fill its place.

And yet this hasn't deterred the authorities from continuing the TV blackout in an effort to stop Pakistanis hearing about the events of the last three days - the detention of several thousand activists, the protests by loyalists across the country, the anger of the international community especially the U.S.
at Musharraf's crackdown.
The only TV news still on air is state-run.

And today, it was concentrating on the information the government wants to spread - an announcement that Musharraf is still determined to quit as army chief and become a civilian president, and that the elections will be on time.
Mazhar Abbas, deputy news director at the private TV news channel ARY, says his staff are still working.
The channel is transmitting overseas, but not to Pakistan.
The security forces, he says, have been roughing up journalists and seizing films all the same.
They knew that, although the channels are off air, they know that the people of Pakistan cannot see these channels in Pakistan.
But even then, they're getting rough even with the cameramen, you know, who are on the street.
In an outdoor food plaza in Islamabad, Amar Kalik(ph) is sitting with a friend.
Kalik is of Pakistani origin but lives in London.
He's visiting his family and trying to figure out what's really going on.
It's whether (unintelligible), whatever your neighbor tell you, whatever your friends and family are going to tell you is what you're going to believe.
It's ridiculous.
Kalik says Pakistanis do care greatly about Musharraf's crackdown, but he adds...
Although there is a very strong public opinion against what's happening at the moment.
Nothing seems to effect the government.
I mean, I don't think they give a damn about public opinion.
They don't.
Philip Reeves, NPR News, Islamabad.
During World War II, many Americans watched history unfold through newsreels like this one.
(Soundbite of newsreel)
Iwo Jima is conquered.
Only isolated snipers remain.
Its airstrips are already in use by American super-fortresses.
Today, Web sites like myspace.com are changing the way people understand the experiences of soldiers fighting abroad.
Armed with handheld cameras and high-speed Internet connections, soldiers can record history as it happens.
NPR's David Nogueras explains.
The social networking Web site MySpace is a natural match for the geographically scattered but tight-knit world of the military.
Users have a free Web page where they can upload photos, music, blog entries or videos.
The video clips might be footage they've shot themselves or just something they want to share with their friends, both military and civilian.
If you do a video search on myspace.com for Iraq or Afghanistan, you might see this.
(Soundbite of video)
This is where Saddam got caught, and this is the dog and this is Trisha.
Or this.
(Soundbite of video)
Unidentified Man #1: So we were ordered by the 56th brigade combat team to blow this bitch up.
You guys ready?
Unidentified Man #2: Ready.
Unidentified Man #1: All right.
Blow it up.
(Soundbite of explosion)
Unidentified Man #2: Yes!
With nearly 100 million user profiles MySpace has become one of the most visited Web sites in the U.S.
That popularity has included members of the military.
Jeff Berman is a senior vice President for public affairs at MySpace.com.
He says MySpace can show the real lives of soldiers in a way you won't see on the nightly news.
And in large part that's because it's unfiltered content.
The soldiers are able to post about their own experiences for their friends, for their family and for everyone else who comes across their page.
If you're posting compelling unique content, people are going to find it and you're going to find your audience.
And sometimes that audience is larger than expected.
This sleek combat music video has been posted hundreds of times on My Space and across the Internet.
(Soundbite of video)
Unidentified Man #3: This is what people join the Marine Corps to do.
You might be in the Marine Corp for 20 years and never get this chance again, to take down a full-fledged city full of insurgents.
Hello.
Good to be here.
Now, let's, talk about these movies and their success at the box office.
Critically acclaimed, but not drawing in large numbers.
